summary: The group introduced themselves to each other and discussed their roles in the project. The Project Manager opened a discussion about the project plan and asked the Marketing Expert to prepare an overall plan for the project. The Marketing Expert presented the initial aim of the project: the creation of a fresh, user-friendly remote control device. The Project Manager asked the Industrial Designer to create a functional design plan for the device, then asked the Marketing Expert about ideas for the sales strategy. The Marketing Expert presented an initial sales plan: to analyze the competition and to pinpoint the target marketing group. The Project Manager instructed all participants to work together on their respective design plans. The Project Manager decided that the design plans will be discussed at the next meeting, and that the next step will be to come up with a functional design of the device.
actions: The Marketing Expert will prepare a sales plan for the product and discuss the project budget and the sales strategy. The Industrial Designer will prepare an initial functional design. The User Interface Designer will contribute studies on user requirements to the functional design. The Project Manager will post his presentation to be available for all participants.
decisions: The group will discuss the design plans of the three experts at the next meeting. The group will first work on a functional design of the device.
problems: The group did not receive sufficient information about the project in advance to be prepared to create a project plan in the first meeting.

Conceptual Design meeting
Presented by: Sridhar Dasari, Project Manager
Agenda
Opening
PM = secretary (minutes)
3 presentations
Decision on remote control concepts
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
Decisions
Components concept?
Energy?
Chip on print
Case
User interface concept?
Interface
Type
Supplements
Closing
Next meeting starts in 30 minutes
Individual actions
ID: the look-and-feel design 
UID: the user-interface design 
ME: product evaluation 
ID and UID work together on prototype using modeling clay
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Detailed Design meeting
Presented by: Sridhar Dasari Project Manager
Agenda
Opening
PM = secretary (minutes)
Prototype presentation
Evaluation criteria
Finance
Production evaluation
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
Finance
Excel sheet

Are the cost under 12.50 euro?

Project evaluation

Room for creativity
Leadership

Means (e.g., whiteboard, digital pens, etc.)
New ideas found?
Closing

Is the project evaluated?
Then: Celebration!

Functional Design meeting
Presented by: Sridhar Dasari, Project Manager
Agenda
Opening
Project Manager = secretary (minutes)
3 presentations
New project requirements
Decision on remote control functions
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
Closing
Now: lunch break
Then 30 minutes of individual work
PM: puts minutes in Project Documents folder
Individual actions
ID: the components concept 
UID: the user interface concept 
ME: trend watching 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Kick-Off meeting
Presented by: <Dasari Sridhar, Project Manager
Agenda
Opening
Acquaintance
Tool training 
Project plan
Discussion
Closing (we have 25 minutes!)
Project Aim
New remote control
Original
Trendy
User friendly
Project Method
Functional design 
Individual work
Meeting
Conceptual design
Individual work
Meeting
Detailed design
Individual work
Meeting
Tool Training
Try out the whiteboard!
Participants can draw their favorite animal and list its favorite characteristics
Project Finance
Selling price: 25 euro
Profit aim: 50 MEuro
Market range: international
Production costs: max. 12.50 euro
Discussion
Examples:
Experience with remote control
First ideas new remote
Etc.
Closing
Next meeting starts in 30 minutes
Individual actions
ID: the working design
UID: the technical functions design 
ME: the user requirements specification 
Specific instructions will be send to you by your personal coach.

Components Design
Presented by: Christine
Industrial Designer
Method
Conceptual specification of components
Case 
Power
Beam
Microphone
Speaker
Materials
Evaluate use in the past
Evaluate new materials
Contact Manufacturing for their input
Findings
Materials for curved case
Rubber 
Plastic
Titanium
Wood
Chips
Simplebuttons 
regular 
advanced chip on print
The chip on print includes an infrared sender. Furthermore we just developed a sample sensor/ sample speaker
Personal Preferences
Designer woods
Carvings or engravings on order
Solar cells
Microphone and Speaker on advanced chip

Working Design
Presented by: Christine 
Industrial Designer
Method
Identify User requirements
Turn television on and off the first time you press on the big button
Easy to find and hold
Identify things that are popular 
iPod
Nokia camera phone
Determine the materials to use
History
Zenith engineer Eugene Polley invented the "Flashmatic," which represented the industry's first wireless TV remote. 
Introduced in 1955, Flashmatic operated by means of four photo cells, one in each corner of the TV screen. The viewer used a highly directional flashlight to activate the four control functions, which turned the picture and sound on and off and changed channels by turning the tuner dial clockwise and counter-clockwise.
While it pioneered the concept of wireless TV remote control, the Flashmatic had some limitations. 
It was a simple device that had no protection circuits and, if the TV sat in an area in which the sun shone directly on it, the tuner might start rotating.
Findings
Infrared bulb
Bulb  
Switch  
Energy source 
Wire
Chip  
Subcomponent  
Components
Personal Preferences
Inflatable (so that the size can vary according to user preferences)
Colorful or Transparent
Waterproof
Beeps (loudly) or plays a tune
Long battery life

Interface Concept
Presented by: Agnes,
User Interface Designer
Functionalities Used
Visible
On/off switch
Volume and channel control
Menu access button
Ergonomic shape for easy holding
Flip screen
Battery life light
Invisible
Audio and tactile feedback of button presses
Single word speech recognition

Interface Concept
Presented by: Agnes
User Interface Designer
Specifying the case
i. Form  - ergonomic shape
ii. Material - wood
iii. Color - customizable
Interface Elements
 i. Function 
Turn on/off
Volume and channel control
Menu control
Voice recognition control
LCD screen on flip panel
ii. Position 
The grand unveiling …

Technical Functions Design
Presented by: Agnes,  
User Interface Designer
Method
Need to look at what people like and don’t like about existing TV remote controls
Need to look at why the good ideas are good and the bad ideas are bad
May seem simple, but it’s not!
What functionalities do we want to use/keep
What should the remote look like
Needed/Useful functionalities
Turn TV on/off
Change channels
directly
Surfing
Control the volume
Control menus on the tv

Problems
Too many buttons on remote controls
What buttons do isn’t clear
Often need to know specific button sequences
Buttons are too small
Some examples
Personal Preferences
Keep number of buttons to a minimum
Make frequently used buttons bigger and more strategically placed
Keep the design sleek and simple

Evaluation criteria
Presented by: <Ed >, Marketing Expert
Method
Independent study shows that the market buys nearly 8m per year
Internal company evaluation- market will
purchase between 8-9 m remotes next year
Findings
- Target of 2m units to be sold
- Price must be 50€
- Production cost cannot exceed 25€
(obviously material, labor, transport,
promotion)
Company must take 25% of the market
(over one year period)
Evaluation
1 Form
2 Fancy, stylish
3 Ease of use
4 Speech recognition
5 Cost
Company must evaluate feasibility of being able to capture enough of the market to justify putting new remote into production.

Trend Watching
Presented by: Marketing Expert
Method
<We have been giving sample questionnaires in various areas to be able to make decisions as to what consumers are looking for.>

Findings
The market trend is toward « fancy and feel good » style of remotes.
Consumers are looking for the « next » major inovation. 
Easy to use has again become a major interest with consumers.
Consumers are willing to pay for new, exciting technology.
Personal Preferences

SUMMARY – MEETING #2
[ABSTRACT] 
The project manager told us about the new project requirements. We discussed implementation points in more details (both for industrial design and user interface). I presented the very first components block-diagram.
[DECISIONS]
Decision has been made to go on with the technical staff proposals. Thanks to the marketing expert, we decided to embed a speech recognition system into the remote control (value-added feature), in order to “jump” directly to the desired channel.
[PROBLEMS/ISSUES]
How to get and process the information coming from the TV set, so as to address the content-based navigation problem. Find the cheapest hardware possible. 
[ACTIONS]
I will learn more about speech recognition. Project manager will help with introductions to Intel and IBM

SUMMARY – MEETING #3
[ABSTRACT] 
The concept of making a remote control in wood was well received and we agreed that this would be a breakthrough
[DECISIONS]
We decided to continue to explore the option of a flip screen
[PROBLEMS / ISSUE]
We are running out of time, there isn’t enough information about certain parameters
[ACTIONS]
build prototypes.

SUMMARY – MEETING #4
[ABSTRACT] 
We present our colorful prototype with LCD display in the flip top…and discuss the cost, as well as the marketing issues. 
[DECISIONS]
We decided to proceed with our wooden case design and to do a test marketing before a major sports event. And to use the sports event as a venue for the launch.
[PROBLEMS / ISSUE]
we may not have sufficient user input into the final design and this could be a fatal drawback.
[ACTIONS]
the product prototypes will be developed and tested in the market prior to launch. We will use online ordering and order fulfillment in order to cut costs and to expedite the delivery of custom solutions

[ABSTRACT]   Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the meeting as a whole from your role’s perspective.
 
 I felt that the meeting could have gone better. The project was not well defined PRIOR to the meeting. It would have been helpful to have had more guidance about what was expected prior to going into the meeting. I think the project manager should take into account the fact that participants have multiple projects with different priorities.

I didn’t catch any action items assigned to others

[ABSTRACT]   Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the meeting as a whole from your role’s perspective.
 
 
In this meeting we discussed briefly who the participants are and what roles they will be playing. Then we had a quick introduction to the project, with some confusion about what the goal of the project is. The marketing and industrial design reps were then asked to give overviews of their plans, or at least a timeframe for when the plans would be ready. Both agreed that it was too early to have concrete plans. The user interface designer was asked if they would be coordinating, and the answer was that no, they wouldn’t be but that they would still need to interact closely with both marketing and industrial design to determine and meet user requirements needs. Budget was also briefly discussed. 
 
 
 
 
 
	 
	[DECISIONS]   Name all decisions that were made during the meeting. Mark those decisions that you consider of high importance for your role with a *. Write fragmented notes.
- an industrial design plan draft would be available soon
	a marketing draft plan would be available soon
	everyone would be cced on all correspondence*
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	[PROBLEMS/ISSUES] Name the problems or difficulties that occurred during the meeting. Mark those that you consider of high importance for your role with a *. Write fragmented notes.
	 - not enough information was given about the project as a whole – aims, budget, workplan*
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	[ACTIONS]  Name the next steps that each member will take until the next meeting. Write fragmented notes.
UID – start looking at usability and user requirements
Marketing – preliminary draft of marketing plan, look at competition etc
Industrial design - preliminary ideas for design

Next, the marketing perspective was presented, again with comments and questions following. Finally, the interface design perspective was presented. Each presentation highlighted some desired functionalities.

[ABSTRACT]   Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the meeting as a whole from your role’s perspective.
 
 The project manager went over the budget for the prototype. It was thought to be a little underestimated. Then, the prototype was unveiled and all the features were explained. The marketing manager then pointed out some other financial issues and considerations, mainly that the actual cost per unit would be higher than projected by the project manager. We then discussed the possibility of web-marketing and seasonal testing and releases, to correspond to potential peaks in the market. 
 
 
 The proposed model was unveiled before the team members.The industrial designer talked about the feel good feature of the model.The user interface designer discussed about the various features such as the buttons , there function.shape,colour of the model.
Then the market expert evaluated the model and came to the conclusion that the model has good chances of

	Try to include more features to make it more attractive.
	Right time to laounch the product into the market
	
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	[PROBLEMS/ISSUES] Name the problems or difficulties that occurred during the meeting. Mark those that you consider of high importance for your role with a *. Write fragmented notes.
 
	 
	By including the voice recognition system which may hike the selling and production rate.A descision has to be taken to include the feature and to keep the expenditure within budget.
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	[ACTIONS]  Name the next steps that each member will take until the next meeting. Write fragmented notes.
To launch the product in the market with enhanced feature at the right time.

But as the meeting went on, it became easier to come up with an idea and strategy of what we will need to do. It will certainly be more coherent in future meetings.
